{{Other people|James Fowler}} '''James W. Fowler III''' (October 12, 1940 – October 16, 2015) was an American theologian who was Professor of Theology and Human Development at [[Emory University]]. He was director of both the Center for Research on Faith and Moral Development and the Center for Ethics until he retired in 2005. He was a minister in the [[United Methodist Church]].http://www.myajc.com/news/news/local-obituaries/james-w-fowler-75-theologian-author-embodied-the-f/nn7P7/{{sfn|Evans|2010|p=196}} ==Stages of Faith== He is best known for his book ''Stages of Faith'', published in 1981, in which he sought to develop the idea of a [[Developmental psychology|developmental]] process in "human faith". {{sfn|Evans|2010|p=196}} These [[stages of faith development]] were along the lines of [[Jean Piaget]]'s [[theory of cognitive development]] and [[Lawrence Kohlberg]]'s [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development|stages of moral development]].{{sfn|Evans|2010|pp=196-197}} ===Description of the stages=== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right;" ! No. ! Fowler ! Age ! [[Jean Piaget|Piaget]] |- | 6 | Fowler | Universalizing | 45+? | Piaget rowspan=4 | Formal-operational |- | 5 | Fowler rowspan=1 | Conjunctive | Age rowspan=1 | 35+ years? |- | 4 | Fowler | Individual-Reflective | Age | 21+ years? |- | 3 | Fowler | Synthetic-
Conventional | Age | 12+ years |- | 2 | Fowler | Mythic-
Literal | Age | 7–12 years | Piaget | Concrete operational |- | 1 | Fowler | Intuitive-
Projective | Age | 2–7 years | Piaget | Pre-operational |- | 0 | Fowler rowspan=1 | Undifferentiated
Faith | Age rowspan=1 | 0–2 years | Piaget rowspan=1 | Sensoric-motorical |- |} * '''Stage 0''' – ''"Primal or Undifferentiated"'' faith (birth to 2 years), is characterized by an early learning of the safety of their environment (i.e. warm, safe and secure vs. hurt, neglect and abuse). If consistent nurture is experienced, one will develop a sense of trust and safety about the universe and the divine. Conversely, negative experiences will cause one to develop distrust with the universe and the divine. Transition to the next stage begins with integration of thought and language which facilitates the use of symbols in speech and play. * '''Stage 1''' – ''"Intuitive-Projective"'' faith (ages of three to seven), is characterized by the psyche's unprotected exposure to the [[Unconscious mind|Unconscious]], and marked by a relative fluidity of thought patterns.Joann Wolski Conn (ed.), Women’s Spirituality: Resources for Christian Development. (Paulist, 1986), pp. 226-232 Religion is learned mainly through experiences, stories, images, and the people that one comes in contact with. * '''Stage 2''' – ''"Mythic-Literal"'' faith (mostly in school children), stage two persons have a strong belief in the [[justice]] and reciprocity of the universe, and their [[deity|deities]] are almost always [[anthropomorphic]]. During this time metaphors and symbolic language are often misunderstood and are taken literally. * '''Stage 3''' – ''"Synthetic-Conventional"'' faith (arising in adolescence; aged 12 to adulthood) characterized by [[conformity]] to authority and the religious development of a personal identity. Any conflicts with one's beliefs are ignored at this stage due to the fear of threat from inconsistencies. * '''Stage 4''' – ''"Individuative-Reflective"'' faith (usually mid-twenties to late thirties) a stage of [[angst]] and struggle. The individual takes personal responsibility for his or her [[belief]]s and [[feeling]]s. As one is able to reflect on one's own beliefs, there is an openness to a new complexity of faith, but this also increases the awareness of conflicts in one's belief. * '''Stage 5''' – ''"Conjunctive"'' faith (mid-life crisis) acknowledges paradox and [[transcendence (philosophy)|transcendence]] relating reality behind the symbols of inherited systems. The individual resolves conflicts from previous stages by a complex understanding of a multidimensional, interdependent "truth" that cannot be explained by any particular statement. * '''Stage 6''' – ''"Universalizing"'' faith, or what some might call "[[Enlightenment (spiritual)|enlightenment]]". The individual would treat any person with compassion as he or she views people as from a universal community, and should be treated with universal principles of love and justice. ==Empirical research== Fowler's model has inspired a considerable body of empirical research into faith development, although little of such research has been conducted by Fowler himself. A useful tool here has been Gary Leak's Faith Development Scale, or FDS, which has been subject to [[factor analysis]] by Leak (Leak, 2008). For criticism see [[Psychology of religion#Developmental approaches to religion|Developmental approaches to religion]]. ==Publications== *''Stages of Faith: The Psychology of Human Development and the Quest for Meaning'' (1981) {{ISBN|0-06-062866-9}} *''Becoming Adult, Becoming Christian: Adult Development and Christian Faith'' (1984) (revised 1999 {{ISBN|0-7879-5134-X}}) *''To See the Kingdom: The Theological Vision of H. Richard Niebuhr'' (1974), {{ISBN|978-0-687-42300-2}} *''Faith Development and Pastoral Care'' (1987) {{ISBN|0-8006-1739-8}} *''Weaving the New Creation: Stages of Faith and the Public Church'' (1991) {{ISBN|0-06-062845-6}} *''Faithful Change: The Personal and Public Challenges of Postmodern Life'' (1996) {{ISBN|978-0-687-01730-0}} ==See also== *[[Jean Piaget]], [[Theory of cognitive development]] *[[Erik Erikson]], [[Erikson's stages of psychosocial development]] *[[Lawrence Kohlberg]], [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development]] *[[Developmental psychology]] **[[Developmental stage theories]] *[[Psychology of religion]] *[[Integral theory (Ken Wilber)|Integral theory]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|first1=Nancy|last1=Evans |first2=Deanna |last2=Forney |first3=Florence |last3=Guido |first4=Lori |last4=Patton |first5=Kristen |last5=Renn |title=Student Development in College: Theory, Research, and Practice |edition=Second |publisher=Jossey-Bass |location=|year=2010 |isbn=978-0787978099 |ref=harv}} ==Further reading== *Fowler, James W. (1981). ''Stages of Faith'', Harper & Row {{ISBN|0-06-062866-9}}. *Leak, G. (2008). Factorial validity of the Faith Development Scale. ''[[The International Journal for the Psychology of Religion]]'', 18 (2) pp123ff. *Stanley Rothman, S. Robert Lichter, and Neil Nevitte (2005) "Politics and Professional Advancement Among College Faculty," The Forum: Vol. 3 : Iss. 1, Article 2. Available at: https://web.archive.org/web/20120111103650/http://www.bepress.com/forum/vol3/iss1/art2/ *Stanley Rothman, S. Robert Lichter, and Neil Nevitte, Fundamentals and Fundamentalists: A Reply to Ames et al.2 (July 2005) *Wulff, D. M., ''Psychology of Religion: Classic and Contemporary'' (2nd ed), New York, Wiley, 1997. *Zastrow, C., Kirst-Ashman, K. (2007). ''Understanding human behavior and the social environment'' (7th ed.) Belmont, CA: Brooks/Cole. *Volume dedicated to the Faith Development Theory of James Fowler in ''[[The International Journal for the Psychology of Religion]]''. '''11'''(3). 2001. For example: **Heinz Streib, "The Symposium on Faith Development Theory and the Modern Paradigm", pp. 141–142. **John McDargh "Faith Development Theory and the Postmodern Problem of Foundations", pp. 185–199 **Howard Kurtz, "College Faculties a Most Liberal Lot, Study Finds", WP, Tuesday 29 Mar 2005, p. C1. ==External links== *[http://ethics.emory.edu/people/Founder.html James W.Fowler page at Emory Center for Ethics] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060901213906/http://thejourney.typepad.com/the_journey/2006/07/stages_of_faith_2.html A synopsis of Fowler's Stages of Faith Consciousness] *[http://theologytoday.ptsem.edu/apr1982/v39-1-tabletalk1.htm Craig R. Dykstra "Transformation in Faith and Morals"] ''Theology Today'' '''39'''(1) *[http://jmm.aaa.net.au/articles/2219.htm James Fowler's Stages of Faith in Profile] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141010133734/http://faculty.plts.edu/gpence/html/fowler.htm] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fowler, James W.}} [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:Emory University faculty]] [[Category:Writers from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Psychology of religion]] [[Category:Stage theories]] [[Category:American United Methodist clergy]]

{{Infobox Korean name |hangul={{linktext|한국|해양|수산|개발|원}} |hanja={{linktext|韓國|海洋|水産|開發|院}} |rr=Hangung Haeyang Susan Gaebarwon |mr=Han'gung Haeyang Susan Kaebarwŏn |}} The '''Korea Maritime Institute''' ('''KMI''') is a think tank and research center developing [[South Korea]]n policies on marine affairs and fisheries, operated by the South Korean government through the ''Office of Government Policy Coordination''. KMI was established under its current name in 1997, though expanded from a research center created in 1984 specializing in shipping economics.<ref name=brochure>{{citation |url=http://www.kmi.re.kr/download/kmi200811(eng).pdf |title=Korea Maritime Institute brochure |year=2008 |publisher=Korea Maritime Institute |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref>
KMI is organized into five research divisions as of 2011: *Marine & Coastal Policy Research Department *Shipping, Port & Logistics Research Department *Fisheries Policy Research Department *Marine Territory and Industry Research Department *Fisheries Outlook Center
and has two overseas centers: *Shanghai Research Center *Korea-US Marine Policy Joint Research Center, at the [[University of Rhode Island]]
KMI is headquartered in [[Mapo-gu]], [[Seoul]],<ref name=brochure /> having a staff of about 180.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/2009/03/180_32256.html |title=Institute Offers Strategic Vision for Korean Maritime Industry |date=6 October 2008 |publisher=Korea Times |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref>

revision.text: '''L2 Syntactical Complexity Analyzer''' (L2SCA) developed by [[Xiaofei Lu]] at the [[Pennsylvania State University]], is a computational tool which produces [[language complexity|syntactic complexity]] indices of written English language texts.{{cite web|url=http://aihaiyang.com/software/l2sca/|title=L2 Syntactic Complexity Analyzer|date=12 September 2018|publisher=Aihaiyang.com}} Along with [[Coh-Metrix]], the L2SCA is one of the most extensively used computational tool to compute indices of [[second language writing]] development. The L2SCA is also widely utilised in the field of [[corpus linguistics]].{{cite web|url=https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9789401786447|title=Computational Methods for Corpus Annotation and Analysis|date=12 September 2018|publisher=[[Springer Publishing]] }} The L2SCA is available in a single and a batch mode. The first provides the possibility of analyzing a single written text for 14 syntactic complexity indices. The latter allows the user to analyze 30 written texts simultaneously. ==Usage== ===Second language writing development=== The L2SCA has been used in numerous studies in the field of second language writing development to compute indices of syntactic complexity. {{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1060374315000417|title=Diane Mazgutova & Judit Kormos: Syntactic and lexical development in an intensive English for Academic Purposes programme|date=12 September 2018|publisher=[[Journal of Second Language Writing]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.jbe-platform.com/content/journals/10.1075/dujal.5.1.04loe|title=Junping Hou, Marjolijn Verspoor & Hanneke Loerts: An exploratory study into the dynamics of Chinese L2 writing development|date=12 September 2018|publisher=Dutch Journal of Applied Linguistics}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lancaster.ac.uk/fass/events/laelpgconference/papers/v08/Attila-M-Wind.pdf|title=Attila M. Wind: Second language writing development from a Dynamic Systems Theory perspective|date=12 September 2018|publisher=[[Lancaster University]]}} ===Corpus linguistics=== The L2SCA has also been used in various studies in the field of [[corpus linguistics]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1060374315000405|title=Lu & Ai: Syntactic complexity in college-level English writing: Differences among writers with diverse L1 backgrounds|date=September 2015|publisher=[[Science direct]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.birmingham.ac.uk/Documents/college-artslaw/corpus/conference-archives/2017/general/paper37.pdf|title=Nasseri: A Corpus-based Analysis of Syntactic Complexity measures in the Academic Writing of EFL, ESL, and Native English Master’s Students|date=12 September 2018|publisher=Birmingham.ac.uk}} ==Indices== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" |- !No. ! !Construct !Index !Abbr.[[#notes qr1|1]] |- |1. |rowspan="9" colspan="2"|Syntactic structures |[[Word count]] |W |- |2. |[[Sentence (linguistics)|Sentence]] |S |- |3. |[[Verb phrase]] |VP |- |4. |[[Clause]] |C |- |5. |[[T-unit]] |T |- |6. |[[Dependent clause]] |DC |- |7. |Complex T-unit |CT |- |8. |Coordinate phrase |CP |- |9. |Complex nominal |CN |- |10. |rowspan="14"|Syntactic complexity indices |rowspan="3"|Length of production units |Mean length of sentence |MLS |- |11. |Mean length of T-unit |MLT |- |12. |Mean length of clause |MLC |- |13. |rowspan="3"|[[Coordination (linguistics)|Amounts of coordination]] |Clause per sentence |C/S |- |14. |Verb phrase per T-unit |V/T |- |15. |Clause per T-unit |C/T |- |16. |rowspan="3"|[[Subordination (linguistics)|Amounts of subordination]] |Dependent clause per clause |DC/C |- |17. |Dependent clause per T-unit |DC/T |- |18. |T-unit per sentence |T/S |- |19. |overall sentence complexity |Complex T-unit ratio |CT/T |- |20. |rowspan="4"|Phrasal sophistication |Coordinate phrase per T-unit |CP/T |- |21. |Coordinate phrase per clause |CP/C |- |22. |Complex nominal per T-unit |CN/T |- |23. |Complex nominal per clause |CN/C |} ;Notes * Note 1: Abbreviation ==See also== *[[Coh-Metrix]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==See also== *[[Coh-Metrix]] == External links == * {{official website|http://aihaiyang.com/software/l2sca/}} {{Second language writing}} [[Category:Computational linguistics]] [[Category:Applied linguistics]] [[Category:Second language writing]] {{comp-ling-stub}}

'''Language migration''' may refer to various types of [[language change]], including change associated with [[human migration]] and [[language contact]].
Particular language migrations may have names (for example [[Bantu expansion]]) and particular languages may have notable migration histories (for example [[Indo-Aryan languages|Indo-Aryan]]).
Language contact describes changes that occur when languages come into contact, including [[sound change]] and [[external history]].

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Libraries in ''Second Life''}} {{tone|date=January 2014}} ''[[Second Life]]'' (SL) is an [[Immersion (virtual reality)|immersive]] 3D environment that can be used for entertainment and educational purposes. Due to increasing interest in digital services, some [[libraries]] have established virtual services on ''Second Life''.
== History == By 2007, there were more than 40 '''libraries in ''Second Life''''' and the number was increasing as of April 2011.<ref name="ucd" /> Many of those libraries were found in Cybrary City,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libsuccess.org/index.php?title=Cybrary_City|title=Cybrary City - Library Success: A Best Practices Wiki|publisher=}}</ref> part of the information archipelago on ''Second Life''. This place was built for libraries to set up their virtual services and for displaying their resources. Libraries can provide their services while also learning new skills for 21st-century librarianship.
==''Second Life'' libraries==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Caledon Whitehall library 004.png|thumb|A screencap of a virtual library]] -->
[[Library]] services in ''[[Second Life]]'' can be found at the following SL locations:
*Info Island 1 *Info Island 2 *Edu Island *Caledon Library *Healthinfo Island *Imagination Island - Rachelville *ALA Arts Island *Cybrary City 1 *Cybrary City 2<ref name="flying">{{cite web|last=Greenhill|first=Kathryn|title=Flying Librarians of Oz: What's all the fuss about Second Life and what's it got to do with libraries?|url=http://www.slideshare.net/sirexkat/flying-librarians-of-oz-whats-all-the-fuss-about-second-life-and-whats-it-got-to-do-with-libraries|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>
''Second Life'' libraries are examples of [[Virtual learning environment|immersive learning environments]]. Users can interact with the services in practical ways, such as walking around a virtual space. Libraries in ''Second Life'' often put on digital exhibitions as part of their services, for example an exhibit displaying virtual representations of [[Vincent van Gogh|Van Gogh]] paintings, including ''Starry Night''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hill|first=Valerie|author2=Lee, Hyuk-Jin |title=Libraries and immersive learning environments unite in Second Life|journal=Library Hi Tec|year=2009|volume=27|issue=3|pages=338–356|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/journals.htm?articleid=1811857&show=abstract}}</ref> The aim of virtual library services is to attract new users to traditional libraries as well as establishing links with librarians from all over the world.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite journal|last=Chappell |author2=Rachlin, Palmer |author3=Vinson, Zamarripa |title=When Real and Virtual World Collide: A Second Life Library |year=2009 |url=http://www.desktop-computing.com/capstone/Documents/WhenVirtualWorldsCollideFinal.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323051006/http://www.desktop-computing.com/capstone/Documents/WhenVirtualWorldsCollideFinal.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-23 |df= }}</ref> Most of these services are run by volunteers.
There have been numerous initiatives to create educational spaces within ''Second Life''. There are Victorian areas in which residents dress in period clothes, an Egyptian tomb and a Renaissance Island created by the Alliance Second Life Libraries.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite journal|last=Bell|first=L.|author2=Lindbloom, M. |author3=Peters, T. |author4=Pope, K. |title=Virtual Libraries and Education in Virtual Worlds: Twenty-first century library services|journal=Policy Futures in Education|year=2008|volume=6|issue=1|url=http://www.wwwords.co.uk/pdf/validate.asp?j=pfie&vol=6&issue=1&year=2008&article=6_Bell_PFIE_6_1_web}}</ref> Central Missouri State University has also received funding to create a reproduction of 1920s Harlem.<ref>{{cite web|title=Virtual Harlem|url=http://www.evl.uic.edu/core.php?mod=4&type=1&indi=168}}</ref>
Libraries can also put on virtual events such as conferences, seminars and lectures. In 2008 and 2009 Alliance Library System (ALS) organised a conference called ''Virtual Worlds: Libraries, Education and Museums Conference''. It took place in the New Media Consortium Conference Center in ''Second Life'' and was designed to "provide a gathering place for librarians, information professionals, educators, museologists, and others to learn about and discuss the educational, informational, and cultural opportunities of virtual worlds".<ref>{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Lori|title=Virtual Worlds: Libraries, Education and Museums Conference|url=http://lisnews.org/node/29040|publisher=LIS News|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref>
Virtual libraries which are independent, run by volunteers and not affiliated with a traditional [[library]] are often the most successful ones in ''Second Life''. ''Second Life''-only virtual libraries tend to be more successful than the ''Second Life'' branches of public libraries.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Users suggest that the libraries in ''Second Life'' serve a niche population, which results in difficulties with marketing.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Staff of public libraries have different perspectives on SL when they are experimenting with it, which results in general conflict.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
In order to have a successful virtual library in ''Second Life'' there are six different elements that should be considered.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> These are:
*Location *Timing *Funding *Techniques *Organisational baggage *Computing technology<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Examples and projects==
===Alliance Library System (ALS)===
The Alliance Library System<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alliancelibrarysystem.com/|title=Reaching Across Illinois Library System|publisher=}}</ref> is an [[Illinois]] based local library co-operator, providing vital library services to citizens. It serves three sectors: libraries, legislators and communities. It is also one of the nine multitype library systems. Multitype library systems cooperate amongst different library sectors in a community, including academic, public, school, and special libraries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Multicounty Multitype Library Cooperation Systems|url=http://education.state.mn.us/MDE/Learning_Support/Library_Services/Minnesota_Libraries_and_Librarians/Multitype_Library_Systems/index.html|publisher=Minnesota Department of Education|accessdate=24 April 2011}}</ref>
In 2003, the Alliance Library System, the Mid-Illinois Talking Book Center, and the Illinois State Library Talking Book and Braille Service founded Online Programming for All Libraries (OPAL).<ref name=opal>{{cite web|title=Welcome to OPAL: Online Programs for All|url=http://www.opal-online.org/|publisher=Online Programming for All Libraries (OPAL)|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref> [http://www.opal-online.org/ OPAL] is an international cooperative program supported by libraries and organisations that provide web-based service and courses/trainings for library customers and staff. The administrator of OPAL is TAP Information Services. Programs include library training, special events and virtual tours of digital library collections. OPAL events mainly happen online. Those online rooms can be accessed via various ways (e.g. voice-over-IP, text chatting and synchronised browsing) by participants. In 2006, Alliance Library System and OPAL Opened an Alliance of Libraries 2.0 on ''Second Life'' together.<ref name=shifted>{{cite web|title=Second Library |url=http://www.theshiftedlibrarian.com/archives/2006/04/12/second_library.html |publisher=The Shifted Librarian |accessdate=25 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927182406/http://www.theshiftedlibrarian.com/archives/2006/04/12/second_library.html |archivedate=27 September 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In 2006 the Alliance Library System, along with other library organisations, began to investigate the possibility of establishing a library network on Second Life. By late 2006 they had purchased some land in ''Second Life'' and built a virtual library. They started holding discussion groups as well as classes for teens in the library, including courses on podcasting and film-making and an open-mic night.<ref name=SLJ>{{cite web|last=Barack|first=Lauren|title=Library Gets Second Life|url=http://www.schoollibraryjournal.com/article/CA6338703.html|publisher=School Library Journal|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>
In 2007 ALS created a virtual information archipelago called Info Island. The grand opening was on 12–14 October 2007.<ref name=beth>{{cite web|last=Kanter|first=Beth|title=Alliance Library System and Second Life Library/Info Island Official Opening|url=http://beth.typepad.com/beths_blog/2006/10/alliance_librar.html|publisher=Beth's Blog: How Nonprofit Organizations Can Use Social Media to Power Social Networks for Change|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref> Info Island consists of numerous islands housing various libraries and institutions run by the volunteers of the [http://infoisland.org/ Community Virtual Library] as well as Academic libraries such as Stanford University Library<ref>{{cite web|last=Wicklund|first=Deni|title=See the Stanford Libraries' Island in Second Life|url=http://speaking.stanford.edu/highlights/See_SU_Libraries_in_Second_Life.html|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> and government organisations such as the Centres for Disease Control.<ref name=autogenerated3 />
===When real and virtual worlds collide: a ''Second Life'' library===
"When Real and Virtual Worlds Collide: A Second Life Library" is a research paper carried out by Chase Baity, Pam Chappell, David Rachlin, C. Vinson and Marilyn Zamarripa. The group studied traditional public libraries, their ''Second Life'' counterparts, and independent ''Second Life'' in order to find out whether independent ''Second Life'' libraries or libraries affiliated with a Real Life library were the most successful. They used surveys, focus groups, and interviews. Over 350 users and 15 staff members participated in the study.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
The research questions for the study were:
* What are the integrated goals between the real world and virtual world libraries? * What is the optimal way to deliver services to reach these goals that are highly usable for employees and patrons? * How usable currently is the virtual library?<ref name=autogenerated1 />
A secondary question was looking at how other real life and ''Second Life'' libraries are similar to or different from the Olathe project.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
The study found that "Second-Life-only libraries are far more popular than Second Life branches of public libraries".<ref name=autogenerated1 /> They also found that "there are no clear indications of what makes a ''Second Life'' library more or less popular than an other.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
===University College Dublin (UCD) Library in ''Second Life''===
The University College Dublin (UCD) [[UCD Library|James Joyce Library]] built up the first Irish library in Second Life.<ref name="ucd">{{cite web|title=Library Joins Second Life|url=http://www.ucd.ie/news/june07/062707_second_life.html|publisher=UCD News|accessdate=23 April 2011}}</ref> [[University College Dublin]] set up its library in ''Second Life'' in March 2007 as a part of ALS's Cybrary City project.<ref name="jibs">{{cite web|last=McMauley |first=Cathal |title=The Library in Second Life |url=http://www.jibs.ac.uk/events/workshops/web2.0/second-life.ppt |publisher=JIBS |accessdate=30 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727010726/http://www.jibs.ac.uk/events/workshops/web2.0/second-life.ppt |archivedate=27 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> This virtual library has several features and services, including user surveys, e-mail services, e-books, presentations, comment box, virtual PC, notecard giver, trampoline, dance machine and visitor counter. A work group was established for services, technology, staffing and marketing.<ref name="jibs" />
===Caledon Library===
The Independent State of Caledon is an area of ''Second Life'' which is exclusively Victorian-themed.<ref name=caledon>{{cite web|title=Independent State of Caledon |url=http://www.steampunkwiki.com/wiki/Independent_State_of_Caledon |publisher=Steampunk Wiki |accessdate=25 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110508222218/http://www.steampunkwiki.com/wiki/Independent_State_of_Caledon |archivedate= 8 May 2011 |df= }}</ref> It includes its own virtual library.
As well as a traditional building, Caledon Library has an outdoor reading room, the Vannevar Bush Memorial Reading Garden. Users can find a book and sit under a tree to read it.<ref name=caledon2>{{cite web|title=Caledon Library |url=http://infoisland.org/about/caledon/ |publisher=Community Virtual Library |accessdate=25 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724113948/http://infoisland.org/about/caledon/ |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> It also holds book discussion groups and hosts art exhibitions.<ref name="caledon2" />
Caledon Library has two main collection policies. These are 19th-century literature and materials relating to the Independent State of Caledon.<ref name="caledon2" /> They collect primary source material (including 19th-century novels and periodicals or materials from earlier ages considered important in the 19th century) and research materials relating to the 19th century. They are hoping to build a "listening collection" of audio books on these topics. Another project is a collection of materials created by residents of Caledon or items relating to Caledon. Their aspiration is to eventually establish the Caledon Archives.<ref name="caledon2" />
===Other examples of educational libraries in ''Second Life''===
* Many US universities in ''Second Life'' such as [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]], [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]] and [[Princeton University|Princeton]]. * Universities from the following countries: UK, Australia, Denmark, France, The Netherlands etc. * UCLA offered a graduate level course, DIS 250 "Techniques and Issues in Information Access: Information Seeking in Second Life"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://polaris.gseis.ucla.edu/jrichardson/courses/250W08.htm|title=UCLA DIS 250 "Techniques and Issues in Information Access: IS in Second Life," Winter 2008, Dr. John V. Richardson Jr.|publisher=}}</ref> during the Winter 2008 term.
==Impact==
Due to changes in modern lifestyle and consumer behaviours, modern customers may not visit local library buildings. This has become a worry and reason for city councils to cut libraries' budgets. Some libraries, such as ALS decided to take the organisations to their customers, transferring from real life into a [[virtual world]].<ref name="SLJ" />
In recent years ''Second Life'' libraries have held discussion groups and planned events. Participant librarians say that responses have been much higher than they thought they could be. For example, in the early days of ALS establishing a virtual library in Second Life, a surprising number of Residents visited the building, with some even asking reference questions.<ref name="SLJ" />
According to successful examples, more and more libraries have realised that ''Second Life'' is a new and good means to interact with their customers, helping traditional libraries to accommodate new demands and challenges.
==Issues for real life librarians==
Some "real life" librarians may find it difficult to balance their duties in their online and offline capacities. Librarians are passionate about their commitments to virtual world libraries to the extent that most librarians completed virtual library work at home and are not compensated by their libraries for this work<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite journal|last=Blankenship|first=Emily|author2=Holingsworth, Yolanda |title=Balancing both lives: issues facing librarians working in Second Life and real life worlds|journal=New Library World|year=2009|volume=110|issue=9/10|pages=430–440|doi=10.1108/03074800910997445|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/journals.htm?issn=0307-4803&volume=110&issue=9/10&articleid=1817279&show=html|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> . This could potentially cause problems with stress and fatigue.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
Librarians also indicated that adequate computing equipment and faster broadband access is important for increasing the productivity and performance of Second Life libraries, and these requirements limit the involvement of numerous librarians.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> Additional issues of computing supports include network security programs that help Second Life libraries to solve problems such as appropriate permissions, authentications, limitations of functionality based on security restrictions and service attacks.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
Additionally, there are some technology challenges. For example, the use of [[radio-frequency identification]] (RFID) – common in most libraries – has become one of the challenges for ''Second Life'' libraries. ''Second Life'' is sometimes unable to get all the information normally stored on RFID devices such as the means keeping track of library books, people or policies.<ref name=sciencedaily>{{cite web|title=3D Library Visit: Using Second Life To Research Everyday Problems|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/03/080330225933.htm|publisher=Science Daily|accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>
==Criticism==
Some professionals have acknowledged that ''Second Life'' offers unique opportunities to expand the horizons of traditional library services.<ref name="ucd" /> In addition, some university librarians believe that ''Second Life'' libraries can be a valuable part of University services, becoming involved in activities such as delivering a downloading service for lecture notes.<ref name="ucd" />
Some studies have found that some librarians did not pay enough attention to pre-planning their ''Second Life'' libraries, despite librarianship having a culture of planning and management.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Most ''Second Life'' librarians have no time to manage a ''Second Life'' Library during their working time because there is not any official timeline that designed by departments.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> As a result, ''Second Life'' libraries are misunderstood by many people who view ''Second Life'' libraries as just games without any educational value. Although the ''Second Life'' library is easier to navigate and provides many useful and good materials, it has few users. The reason is that the ''Second Life'' branch has not been well promoted in real life so library users do not know its existence.<ref name=autogenerated1 />

The following is a '''list of the presidents and executive secretaries of the [[Religious Education Association]]'''.
The [[Religious Education Association]] is a nonprofit member association, serving as a professional and learned society for scholars and researchers involved in the field of religious education. In 2003 it merged formally with the Association of Professors and Researchers in Religious Education. Up until that date, REA presidents could serve for more than a year at a time, while APRRE presidents served for only one year at a time. At the moment of merger, presidential terms were limited to one year and "practitioners" was added to the title of the organization, making it the "Religious Education Association: An Association of Professors, Practitioners and Researchers in Religious Education" (REA: APPRRE).

revision.text:
{{StatsTopicTOC}} '''[[Statistics]]''' is the mathematical science involving the collection, analysis and interpretation of data. A number of specialties have evolved to apply statistical and methods to various disciplines. Certain topics have "statistical" in their name but relate to manipulations of probability distributions rather than to statistical analysis.
*'''[[Actuarial science]]''' is the discipline that applies mathematical and statistical methods to assess risk in the [[insurance]] and [[finance]] industries. *'''[[Astrostatistics]]''' is the discipline that applies statistical analysis to the understanding of astronomical data. *'''[[Biostatistics]]''' is a branch of [[biology]] that studies biological phenomena and observations by means of statistical analysis, and includes [[medical statistics]]. *'''[[Business analytics]]''' is a rapidly developing business process that applies statistical methods to data sets (often very large) to develop new insights and understanding of business performance & opportunities *'''[[Chemometrics]]''' is the science of relating measurements made on a [[chemistry|chemical]] system or process to the state of the system via application of mathematical or statistical methods. *'''[[Demography]]''' is the statistical study of all [[population]]s. It can be a very general science that can be applied to any kind of dynamic population, that is, one that changes over time or space. *'''[[Econometrics]]''' is a branch of [[economics]] that applies statistical methods to the empirical study of economic theories and relationships. *'''[[Environmental statistics]]''' is the application of statistical methods to [[environmental science]]. Weather, climate, air and water quality are included, as are studies of plant and animal populations. *'''[[Epidemiology]]''' is the study of factors affecting the health and illness of populations, and serves as the foundation and logic of interventions made in the interest of public health and preventive medicine. *'''[[Geostatistics]]''' is a branch of [[geography]] that deals with the analysis of data from disciplines such as [[petroleum geology]], [[hydrogeology]], [[hydrology]], [[meteorology]], [[oceanography]], [[geochemistry]], [[geography]]. *'''[[Machine learning]]''' is the subfield of [[computer science]] that formulates algorithms in order to make predictions from data. *'''[[Operations research]]''' (or operational research) is an interdisciplinary branch of applied mathematics and formal science that uses methods such as mathematical modeling, statistics, and algorithms to arrive at optimal or near optimal solutions to complex problems. *'''[[Population ecology]]''' is a sub-field of [[ecology]] that deals with the dynamics of species populations and how these populations interact with the [[environment (biophysical)|environment]]. *'''[[Psychometrics]]''' is the theory and technique of educational and psychological measurement of knowledge, abilities, attitudes, and personality traits. *'''[[Quality control]]''' reviews the factors involved in manufacturing and production; it can make use of [[Sampling (statistics)|statistical sampling]] of product items to aid decisions in [[process control]] or in accepting deliveries. *'''[[Quantitative psychology]]''' is the science of statistically explaining and changing mental processes and behaviors in humans. *'''[[Reliability engineering]]''' is the study of the ability of a system or component to perform its required functions under stated conditions for a specified period of time *'''[[Statistical finance]]''', an area of [[econophysics]], is an empirical attempt to shift finance from its [[Normative economics|normative]] roots to a [[positivist]] framework using exemplars from statistical physics with an emphasis on emergent or collective properties of financial markets. *'''[[Statistical mechanics]]''' is the application of [[probability]] theory, which includes mathematical tools for dealing with large populations, to the field of [[mechanics]], which is concerned with the motion of particles or objects when subjected to a force. *'''[[Statistical physics]]''' is one of the fundamental theories of [[physics]], and uses methods of [[probability]] theory in solving physical problems. *'''[[Statistical signal processing]]''' utilizes the statistical properties of [[signal]]s to perform signal processing tasks. *'''[[Statistical thermodynamics]]''' is the study of the microscopic behaviors of [[thermodynamic system]]s using probability theory and provides a molecular level interpretation of thermodynamic quantities such as [[Work (thermodynamics)|work]], [[heat]], [[Thermodynamic free energy|free energy]], and [[entropy]].

{{EngvarB|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} '''The Lothian birth-cohort studies'''<ref name="Deary et al., 2012">{{Cite journal|title = Cohort Profile: The Lothian Birth Cohorts of 1921 and 1936|url = http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/6/1576|journal = International Journal of Epidemiology|date = 1 December 2012|issn = 0300-5771|pmid = 22253310|pages = 1576–1584|volume = 41|issue = 6|doi = 10.1093/ije/dyr197|first = Ian J.|last = Deary|first2 = Alan J.|last2 = Gow|first3 = Alison|last3 = Pattie|first4 = John M.|last4 = Starr}}</ref> are two ongoing [[Cohort study|cohort studies]] which primarily involve research into how childhood [[intelligence]] relates to intelligence and health in old age. The Lothian Birth Cohort studies of 1921 and 1936 have, respectively, followed up [[Lothian]]-based participants in the Scottish Mental Surveys of 1932 and 1947 in old age.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> Scottish Mental Survey data has provided a measure of the intelligence of Lothian Birth Cohort participants at age 11, which has enabled the investigation of how childhood intelligence relates to cognition, [[mental health]] and physical health in old age.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" />
Major cognitive ageing findings of the studies have concerned the stability of intelligence from childhood to old age,<ref name="Deary et al., 2013">{{Cite journal|title = The Stability of Intelligence From Age 11 to Age 90 Years The Lothian Birth Cohort of 1921|url = http://pss.sagepub.com/content/24/12/2361|journal = Psychological Science|date = 1 December 2013|issn = 0956-7976|pmid = age|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2013.05.032|journal = Neurobiology of Aging|date = 1 January 2013|pmc = 3898072|pmid = 23850341|volume = 34|issue = 12|doi = 10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2013.05.032|first = Maria del C.|last = Valdés Hernández|first2 = Tom|last2 = Booth|first3 = Catherine|last3 = Murray|first4 = Alan J.|last4 = Gow|first5 = Lars|last5 = the vanguard of the field of [[cognitive epidemiology]],<ref name="Deary, 2010">{{Cite journal|title = Cognitive epidemiology: Its rise, its current issues, and its challenges|url = relates to physical and mental health outcomes. The Lothian Birth Cohort studies are led by [[Ian Deary]], the director of the [[CCACE|Centre for Cognitive Ageing and Cognitive Epidemiology]] at the [[University of Edinburgh]].
==Background== The Lothian Birth Cohort (LBC) studies of 1921 (LBC1921) and 1936 (LBC1936) are follow-up studies of, respectively, the Scottish Mental Surveys (SMSs) of 1932 (SMS1932) and 1947 (SMS1947).<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> The Scottish Mental Surveys, which were undertaken by the [[Scottish Council for Research in Education]] (SCRE), are the only attempts to date of any country to measure the intelligence of a complete year-of-birth in its population.<ref name="CCACE, 2015">CCACE (2015). The Scottish Mental Survey 1932 [web page]. Retrieved from http://www.lothianbirthcohort.ed.ac.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6&Itemid=13</ref> By following up SMS participants in old age, the LBC studies have been able to effectively investigate long-term cognitive ageing and cognitive epidemiology due to the availability of a measure of participants' childhood intelligence.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" />
The Moray House Test No. 12, designed by [[Godfrey Thomson]], was used in both Scottish Mental Surveys.<ref name="Deary et al., 2004">{{Cite journal|title = The Impact of Childhood Intelligence on Later Life: Following Up the Scottish Mental Surveys of 1932 and 1947.|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.86.1.130|journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|date = 1 January 2004|volume = 86|issue = 1|doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.86.1.130|first = Ian J.|last = Deary|first2 = Martha C.|last2 = Whiteman|first3 = John M.|last3 = Starr|first4 = Lawrence J.|last4 = Whalley|first5 = Helen C.|last5 = Fox|pages=130–147|pmid=14717632}}</ref> It is a valid intelligence test<ref name="Deary et al., 2004" /> that consists of 75 items of a variety of types including: following directions; word classification; analogies; practical items; reasoning; arithmetic; and spatial items.<ref name="Scottish Council for Research in Education, 1933 cited in Deary et al., 2000">{{Cite journal|title = The Stability of Individual Differences in Mental Ability from Childhood to Old Age: Follow-up of the 1932 Scottish Mental Survey|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289699000318|journal = Intelligence|date = 1 February 2000|pages = 49–55|volume = 28|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/S0160-2896(99)00031-8|first = Ian J|last = Deary|first2 = Lawrence J|last2 = Whalley|first3 = Helen|last3 = Lemmon|first4 = J. R|last4 = Crawford|first5 = John M|last5 = Starr}}</ref>
===Scottish Mental Surveys of 1932 and 1947=== The SMS1932 was funded by the [[Carnegie Corporation of New York|Carnegie Corporation]] as part of the International Examination Inquiry.<ref name="Deary et al., 2008">{{Cite journal|title = A conversation between Charles Spearman, Godfrey Thomson, and Edward L. Thorndike: The International Examinations Inquiry Meetings 1931–1938.|url = http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/1093-4510.11.2.122|journal = History of Psychology|date = 1 January 2008|volume = 11|issue = 2|doi = 10.1037/1093-4510.11.2.122|first = Ian J.|last = Dreary|first2 = Martin|last2 = Lawn|first3 = David J.|last3 = Bartholomew|pages=122–142}}</ref> It aimed to find out how many children in Scotland were "mentally deficient" and gather information on the entire distribution of intelligence in Scottish pupils.<ref name="Scottish Council for Research in Education, 1933 cited in Deary et al., 2000"/> It was conducted on 1 June 1932, and tested the intelligence of almost all of Scotland's 1921-born population, 87,498 children in all.<ref name="Deary et al., 2004" />
The SMS1947 was commissioned to test the theory that average intelligence in the United Kingdom was lower in the new generation due to a negative [[correlation]] between family size and the intelligence of children.<ref name="Deary et al., 2004" /> It was carried out on 4 June 1947, and tested the intelligence of 70,805 children, nearly all of Scotland's 1936-born population.<ref name="Deary et al., 2007">{{Cite journal|title = The Lothian Birth Cohort 1936: a study to examine influences on cognitive ageing from age 11 to age 70 and beyond|url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2318/7/28/abstract|journal = BMC Geriatrics|date = 5 December 2007|issn = 1471-2318|pmc = 2222601|pmid = 18053258|pages = 28|volume = 7|issue = 1|doi = 10.1186/1471-2318-7-28|first = Ian J.|last = Deary|first2 = Alan J.|last2 = Gow|first3 = Michelle D.|last3 = Taylor|first4 = Janie|last4 = Corley|first5 = Caroline|last5 = Brett|first6 = Valerie|last6 = Wilson|first7 = Harry|last7 = Campbell|first8 = Lawrence J.|last8 = Whalley|first9 = Peter M.|last9 = Visscher}}</ref>
===Data rediscovery=== The SMS data was rediscovered by Ian Deary and [[Lawrence Whalley]] in the late 1990s.<ref name="Deary, 2012">Deary, I. J. (2012). ''An Intelligent Scotland: Professor Sir Godfrey Thomson and the Scottish Mental Surveys'' [Lecture recording]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MVGICGmdLiY</ref> The data had been in the [[Moray House School of Education#Charteris Land|Charteris Land]] building of the Moray House School of Education at the University of Edinburgh, which was being rented by the SCRE.<ref name="Deary, 2012" /> Recruitment for the [[Aberdeen]] area-based follow-up studies of the Scottish Mental Surveys, the Aberdeen Birth Cohorts of 1921 and 1936, began in 1997 and 1999 respectively.<ref name="Whalley et al., 2011">{{Cite journal|title = How the 1932 and 1947 mental surveys of Aberdeen schoolchildren provide a framework to explore the childhood origins of late onset disease and disability|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.maturitas.2011.05.010|journal = Maturitas|date = 1 January 2011|volume = 69|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.maturitas.2011.05.010|first = Lawrence J.|last = Whalley|first2 = Alison D.|last2 = Murray|first3 = Roger T.|last3 = Staff|first4 = John M.|last4 = Starr|first5 = Ian J.|last5 = Deary|first6 = Helen C.|last6 = Fox|first7 = Helen|last7 = Lemmon|first8 = Susan J.|last8 = Duthie|first9 = Andrew R.|last9 = Collins|pages=365–372}}</ref>
==Design and aims== A core aim of the LBC studies is to explore causes of different cognitive ageing outcomes.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> They have also been used to facilitate a variety of psychosocial, medical and genetic investigations.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" />
Each wave of data collection typically includes: cognitive tests; socio-demographic information; health behaviours and health status; fitness measures; and physical measures.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> Metabolic and inflammatory [[Biomarker (medicine)|biomarkers]] have also been taken in both cohorts.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> The studies have been funded by a variety of sources, including but not limited to the [[Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council]], the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]], the Scottish Government's [[Chief Scientist Office (Scotland)|Chief Scientist Office]], [[Age UK]] and [[Research into Ageing]].<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" />
===Lothian Birth Cohort 1921=== LBC1921 participant recruitment began in 1999.<ref name="Deary et al., 2004" /> Participants were mainly recruited by tracing SMS1932 participants in the Edinburgh area using the [[National Health Service Central Register#Community Health Index|Community Health Index]] (CHI), and then asking general practitioners to contact the traced potential LBC participants.<ref name="Deary et al., 2004" />
The LBC1921 study's main initial aim was to find molecular genetic markers of healthy cognitive ageing.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> This included the investigation of the influence of the E4 [[allele]] on the [[Apolipoprotein E]] (''APOE'') gene on cognitive ageing as well as testing the effects of other [[candidate gene]]s for cognitive ageing.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> A later research focus was examining relationships involving [[single-nucleotide polymorphisms]] (SNPs) from genes linked to [[oxidative stress]].<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> The third and fourth waves of data collection were conducted with the main objective of testing the common cause hypothesis of cognitive ageing,<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> which puts forward that age-related declines in physical and cognitive functioning share a common cause.<ref name="Christensen et al., 2001">{{Cite journal|title = The "common cause hypothesis" of cognitive aging: Evidence for not only a common factor but also specific associations of age with vision and grip strength in a cross-sectional analysis.|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0882-7974.16.4.588|journal = Psychology and Aging|date = 1 January 2001|volume = 16|issue = 4|doi = 10.1037/0882-7974.16.4.588|first = Helen|last = Christensen|first2 = Andrew J.|last2 = Mackinnon|first3 = Ailsa|last3 = Korten|first4 = Anthony F.|last4 = Jorm|pages=588–599}}</ref>

===Lothian Birth Cohort 1936=== LBC1936 participant recruitment started in 2004.<ref name="Deary et al., 2007" /> Potential participants were identified using the CHI and then sent a letter about the study from the Lothian Health Board.<ref name="Deary et al., 2007" />
The LBC1936 study began with the wider objective of investigating a diverse range of influences on cognitive ageing, including the effects of economic, medical, psychological and social variables.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> For Wave 2, a specific focus was placed on finding how the white matter of the brain becomes damaged and what relationship white matter damage has with age-related cognitive decline.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /><ref name="Wardlaw et al., 2011">{{Cite journal|title = Brain aging, cognition in youth and old age and vascular disease in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936: rationale, design and methodology of the imaging protocol*|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1747-4949.2011.00683.x/abstract|journal = International Journal of Stroke|date = 1 December 2011|issn = 1747-4949|pages = 547–559|volume = 6|issue = 6|doi = 10.1111/j.1747-4949.2011.00683.x|first = Joanna M.|last = Wardlaw|first2 = Mark E.|last2 = Bastin|first3 = Maria C.|last3 = Valdés Hernández|first4 = Susana Muñoz|last4 = Maniega|first5 = Natalie A.|last5 = Royle|first6 = Zoe|last6 = Morris|first7 = Jonathan D.|last7 = Clayden|first8 = Elaine M.|last8 = Sandeman|first9 = Elizabeth|last9 = Eadie}}</ref>

==Findings== As well as being used to research the topics of major findings outlined below, LBC data has been used in a diverse range of other investigations.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" /> For example, LBC1921 participants served as a [[control group]] in a study that validated of the use of the [[National Adult Reading Test]] as a measure of [[Morbidity|premorbid]] cognition in individuals with [[dementia]].<ref name="McGurn et al., 2004">{{Cite journal|title = Pronunciation of irregular words is preserved in dementia, validating premorbid IQ estimation|url = http://www.neurology.org/content/62/7/1184|journal = Neurology|date = 13 April 2004|issn = 0028-3878|pmid = 15079021|pages = 1184–1186|volume = 62|issue = 7|doi = 10.1212/01.WNL.0000103169.80910.8B|first = B.|last = McGurn|first2 = J. M.|last2 = Starr|first3 = J. A.|last3 = Topfer|first4 = A.|last4 = Pattie|first5 = M. C.|last5 = Whiteman|first6 = H. A.|last6 = Lemmon|first7 = L. J.|last7 = Whalley|first8 = I. J.|last8 = Deary}}</ref> LBC1921 data has also been used to find that [[facial symmetry]], as measured by [[fluctuating asymmetry]], is linked to successful cognitive ageing.<ref name="Penke et al., 2009">{{Cite journal|title = Symmetric faces are a sign of successful cognitive aging|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2009.06.001|journal = Evolution and Human Behavior|date = 1 January 2009|volume = 30|issue = 6|doi = 10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2009.06.001|first = Lars|last = Penke|first2 = Timothy C.|last2 = Bates|first3 = Alan J.|last3 = Gow|first4 = Alison|last4 = Pattie|first5 = John M.|last5 = Starr|first6 = Benedict C.|last6 = Jones|first7 = David I.|last7 = Perrett|first8 = Ian J.|last8 = Deary|pages=429–437}}</ref> Data from both Lothian Birth Cohorts has been used to study changes over time in [[Social mobility|social class mobility]]<ref name="Johnson et al., 2010">{{Cite journal|title = Intergenerational class mobility in Britain: A comparative look across three generations in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289609001548|journal = Intelligence|date = 1 March 2010|pages = 268–281|volume = 38|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.intell.2009.11.010|first = Wendy|last = Johnson|first2 = Caroline E.|last2 = Brett|first3 = Ian J.|last3 = Deary}}</ref> and to find strong rank-order stability of [[Trait theory|personality traits]] in old age.<ref name="Mõttus et al., 2012">{{Cite journal|title = Personality traits in old age: Measurement and rank-order stability and some mean-level change.|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/a0023690|journal = Psychology and Aging|date = 1 January 2012|volume = 27|issue = 1|doi = 10.1037/a0023690|first = René|last = Mõttus|first2 = Wendy|last2 = Johnson|first3 = Ian J.|last3 = Deary|pages=243–249}}</ref>
===Stability of intelligence=== [[File:Longitudinal correlations of Moray House Test scores in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1921.png|alt=In the LBC1921, age 11 Moray House Test scores correlated .66, .51 and .55 with scores at ages 79, 87 and 90 respectively. Age 79 scores correlated .7 with age 87 scores and .73 with age 90 scores. Age 87 scores correlated .87 with age 90 scores.|thumb|Path diagram of raw correlations<ref name="Deary et al., 2013" /><ref name="Deary et al., 2004" /><ref name="Gow et al., 2011" /> (displayed on the double-headed arrows) between Moray House Test scores at different ages (displayed within square boxes) in the LBC1921.]]
Studies of the LBC1921 have provided the longest-term estimates of the stability of intelligence.<ref name="Deary et al., 2013" /> They have found that intelligence in childhood is [[Effect size#Pearson r or correlation coefficient|strongly correlated]] with intelligence in old age, and that this correlation exists because intelligence is highly stable trait, rather than because childhood intelligence is linked to rates of cognitive change during adulthood.
The LBC1921 took the Moray House Test at ages 11, 79, 87 and 90, and results at all four sittings were strongly correlated. The raw correlations between test scores at age 11 and at ages 79, 87 and 90 were .66, .51 and .55 respectively, and they rose to .73, .61 and .67 respectively after correction for the restriction of [[Range (statistics)|range]] in the LBC1921 sample.<ref name="Deary et al., 2013" /><ref name="Deary et al., 2004" /><ref name="Gow et al., 2011">{{Cite journal|title = Stability and change in intelligence from age 11 to ages 70, 79, and 87: The Lothian Birth Cohorts of 1921 and 1936.|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/a0021072|journal = Psychology and Aging|date = 1 January 2011|volume = 26|issue = 1|doi = 10.1037/a0021072|first = Alan J.|last = Gow|first2 = Wendy|last2 = Johnson|first3 = Alison|last3 = Pattie|first4 = Caroline E.|last4 = Brett|first5 = Beverly|last5 = Roberts|first6 = John M.|last6 = Starr|first7 = Ian J.|last7 = Deary|pages=232–240}}</ref> The range restriction-corrected correlation coefficients represent the best estimate of the stability of intelligence across the entire population of SMS1932 participants, and indicate that intelligence is a very stable trait.<ref name="Deary et al., 2013" /> Even the corrected coefficients may underestimate the strength of the correlation, as the [[Test-retest reliability|reliability]] of the test is likely below 1.0.<ref name="Deary et al., 2004" />
Although age 11 intelligence is related to old age intelligence, it has been reported to be unrelated to change in intelligence between ages 79 and 87 in the LBC1921.<ref name="Gow et al., 2011" /> This finding suggested that childhood intelligence is related to old age intelligence because of the stability of intelligence rather than because it protects against decline in old age.<ref name="Gow et al., 2011" />
The LBC1936 also re-sat the Moray House Test in old age. In this larger cohort, there was a strong correlation between scores at ages 11 and 70 of .67.<ref name="Gow et al., 2011" />
===Genetic associations=== [[File:PBB Protein APOE.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Apolipoprotein E.|Apolipoprotein E.]]
The most consistent genetic finding from the LBC studies has been that the E4 allele on the ''APOE'' gene, which had previously been known to be a risk factor for late-onset [[Alzheimer's disease]],<ref name="Corder et al., 1993">{{Cite journal|title = Gene dose of apolipoprotein E type 4 allele and the risk of Alzheimer's disease in late onset families|url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/261/5123/921|journal = Science|date = 13 August 1993|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 8346443|pages = 921–923|volume = 261|issue = 5123|doi = 10.1126/science.8346443|first = E. H.|last = Corder|first2 = A. M.|last2 = Saunders|first3 = W. J.|last3 = Strittmatter|first4 = D. E.|last4 = Schmechel|first5 = P. C.|last5 = Gaskell|first6 = G. W.|last6 = Small|first7 = A. D.|last7 = Roses|first8 = J. L.|last8 = Haines|first9 = M. A.|last9 = Pericak-Vance}}</ref> is also adversely linked to non-pathological cognitive function and change.
In an early LBC1921 study, E4 allele status was unrelated to Moray House Test scores at age 11, but at age 80 those with an E4 allele scored lower than those without an E4 allele, indicating that the allele is a risk factor for cognitive decline.<ref name="Deary et al., 2002" /> Later LBC1921 research found that possession of the E4 allele was associated with greater decline in abstract reasoning and verbal memory, but not verbal fluency, between age 79 and age 87.<ref name="Schiepers et al., 2012">{{cite journal |author1=Schiepers O. J. G. |author2=Harris S. E. |author3=Gow A. J. |author4=Pattie A. |author5=Brett C. E. |author6=Starr J. M. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2012 | title = ''APOE'' E4 status predicts age-related cognitive decline in the ninth decade: Longitudinal follow-up of the Lothian Birth Cohort 1921 | url = | journal = [[Molecular Psychiatry]] | volume = 17 | issue = 3| pages = 315–324 | doi = 10.1038/mp.2010.137 }}</ref> Additionally, in the LBC1936, the E4 allele has been associated with worse general cognitive ability at age 70, as well as with worse performance on some specific cognitive tests.<ref name="Luciano et al., 2009">{{cite journal |author1=Luciano M. |author2=Gow A. J. |author3=Harris S. E. |author4=Hayward C. |author5=Allerhand M. |author6=Starr J. M. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2009 | title = Cognitive ability at age 11 and 70 years, information processing speed, and ''APOE'' variation: The Lothian Birth Cohort 1936 study | doi = 10.1037/a0014780 | journal = [[Psychology and Aging]] | volume = 24 | issue = 1| pages = 129–138 }}</ref>
[[Genome-wide association study|Genome-wide association (GWA) studies]] have confirmed the ''APOE'' E4 allele's association with worse cognitive decline and function. A GWA study of longitudinal cohorts, including the LBC1921 and the LBC1936, found that the ''APOE'' E4 allele was associated with deleterious cognitive change.<ref name="Davies et al., 2014">{{cite journal |author1=Davies G. |author2=Harris S. E. |author3=Reynolds C. A. |author4=Payton A. |author5=Knight H. M. |author6=Liewald D. C. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2014 | title = A genome-wide association study implicates the ''APOE'' locus in nonpathological cognitive ageing | doi = 10.1038/mp.2012.159 | journal = [[Molecular Psychiatry]] | volume = 19 | issue = 1| pages = 76–87 }}</ref> Furthermore, a 2015 meta-analysis of GWA studies in 31 cohorts, including the two Lothian Birth Cohorts, found that the ''APOE'' gene as well as SNPs on the ''APOE''/''[[TOMM40]]'' genomic region were associated with general cognitive ability.<ref name="Davies et al., 2015">{{cite journal |author1=Davies G. |author2=Armstrong N. |author3=Bis J. C. |author4=Bressler J. |author5=Chouraki V. |author6=Giddaluru S. |author7=Ford I. | year = 2015 | title = Genetic contributions to variation in general cognitive function: A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies in the CHARGE consortium (''N''=53 949) | doi = 10.1038/mp.2014.188 | journal = [[Molecular Psychiatry]] | volume = 20 | issue = 2| pages = 183–192 }}</ref> Altogether, the ''[[HMGN1]]'' gene, 13 SNPs and four candidate genes, including ''APOE'', were [[Statistical significance|statistically significant]] predictors of general cognitive function.<ref name="Davies et al., 2015" />
Data from both cohorts was also used, in combination with other data, to establish that intelligence is highly [[Polygene|polygenic]].<ref name="Davies et al., 2011">{{cite journal |author1=Davies G. |author2=Tenesa A. |author3=Payton A. |author4=Yang J. |author5=Harris S. E. |author6=Liewald D. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2011 | title = Genome-wide association studies establish that human intelligence is highly heritable and polygenic | doi = 10.1038/mp.2011.85 | journal = [[Molecular Psychiatry]] | volume = 16 | issue = 10| pages = 996–1005 | pmid=21826061 | pmc=3182557}}</ref> In addition, LBC1921 and LBC1936 data was used in calculating the first estimate of the [[genetic correlation]] between childhood and old age intelligence in unrelated individuals, which was .62<ref name="Deary et al., 2012b">{{cite journal |author1=Deary I. J. |author2=Yang J. |author3=Davies G. |author4=Harris S. E. |author5=Tenesa A. |author6=Liewald D. |author7=Visscher P. M. | year = 2012 | title = Genetic contributions to stability and change in intelligence from childhood to old age | doi = 10.1038/nature10781 | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 482 | issue = 7384| pages = 212–215 | pmid=22258510}}</ref> and therefore indicated that most of the stable [[variance]] in intelligence throughout life is attributable to genes rather than environment.
Lothian Birth Cohort data has also been a part of GWA studies for various medical outcomes including cancer, stroke, lung function, arterial pressure and platelet formation.<ref name="Deary et al., 2012" />
===White matter integrity===
[[File:3DSlicer-KubickiJPR2007-fig6.jpg|thumb|right|alt=The structure of the white matter of the human brain.|The structure of the white matter of the human brain.]]
Structural [[magnetic resonance imaging]] brain scans from LBC1936 participants have been used to observe that the integrity of white matter tracts in the brain is linked to cognitive functioning and successful cognitive ageing. In one study, three general [[Factor analysis|factors]] of white matter tract integrity combined to explain 10% of the variance in general intelligence, and this effect was fully [[Mediation (statistics)|mediated]] through processing speed.<ref name="Penke et al., 2012">{{cite journal |author1=Penke L. |author2=Maniega S. M. |author3=Bastin M. E. |author4=Hernandez M. V. |author5=Murray C. |author6=Royle N. A. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2012 | title = Brain white matter tract integrity as a neural foundation for general intelligence | doi = 10.1038/mp.2012.66 | journal = [[Molecular Psychiatry]] | volume = 17 | issue = 10| pages = 1026–1030 | pmid=22614288}}</ref> Later investigation of the associations of specific white matter tracts with ''[[g factor (psychometrics)|g]]'' and specific cognitive abilities found that most specific tract associations were with ''g'' rather than specific abilities, though some associations with specific abilities remained after accounting for associations with ''g''.<ref name="Booth et al., 2013">{{cite journal |author1=Booth T. |author2=Bastin M. E. |author3=Penke L. |author4=Maniega S. M. |author5=Murray C. |author6=Royle N. A. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2013 | title = Brain white matter tract integrity and cognitive abilities in community-dwelling older people: The Lothian Birth Cohort, 1936 | doi = 10.1037/a0033354 | journal = [[Neuropsychology (journal)|Neuropsychology]] | volume = 27 | issue = 5| pages = 595–607 }}</ref>
White matter integrity has also been shown to relate to cognitive change. Specifically, white matter integrity in the [[splenium]] of the corpus callosum has been found to be a marker of healthy cognitive ageing.<ref name="Penke et al., 2010">{{cite journal |author1=Penke L. |author2=Maniega S. M. |author3=Houlihan L. M. |author4=Murray C. |author5=Gow A. J. |author6=Clayden J. D. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2010 | title = White matter integrity in the splenium of the corpus callosum is related to successful cognitive aging and partly mediates the protective effect of an ancestral polymorphism in ''ADRB2'' | doi = 10.1007/s10519-009-9318-4 | journal = [[Behavior Genetics (journal)|Behavior Genetics]] | volume = 40 | issue = 2| pages = 146–156 }}</ref> Lower [[Leukoaraiosis|white matter hyperintensity]] load has also been considered a sign of successful cognitive ageing, because it was associated with higher general cognitive ability and faster processing speed at age 73 after age 11 intelligence was [[Controlling for a variable|controlled for]].<ref name="Hernández et al., 2013" />
Additionally, white matter integrity in some brain areas has been found to be weaker in ''APOE'' E4 allele carriers,<ref name="Lyall et al., 2014">{{cite journal |author1=Lyall D. M. |author2=Harris S. E. |author3=Bastin M. E. |author4=Maniega S. M. |author5=Murray C. |author6=Lutz M. W. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2014 | title = Alzheimer's disease susceptibility genes ''APOE'' and ''TOMM40'', and brain white matter integrity in the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936 | url = | journal = [[Neurobiology of Aging]] | volume = 35 | issue = 6| pages = 1513.e25–1513.e33 | doi = 10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2014.01.006 }}</ref> and weaker white matter integrity has been shown to partially mediate some of the harmful effects of the E4 allele on cognitive change.<ref name="Lyall et al., 2014b">{{cite journal |author1=Lyall D. M. |author2=Harris S. E. |author3=Bastin M. E. |author4=Maniega S. M. |author5=Murray C. |author6=Lutz M. W. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2014 | title = Are ''APOE'' ε genotype and ''TOMM40'' poly-T repeat length associations with cognitive ageing mediated by brain white matter tract integrity? | doi = 10.1038/tp.2014.89 | journal = [[Translational Psychiatry]] | volume = 4 | issue = 9| page = e449 }}</ref>
===Health, health behaviours and cognitive ageing===
In the LBC1921, smoking was linked to greater cognitive decline at age 80.<ref name="Deary et al., 2003">{{cite journal |author1=Deary I. J. |author2=Pattie A. |author3=Taylor M. D. |author4=Whiteman M. C. |author5=Starr J. M. |author6=Whalley L. J. | year = 2003 | title = Smoking and cognitive change from age 11 to age 80 | doi = 10.1136/jnnp.74.7.1006 | journal = [[Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery, and Psychiatry]] | volume = 74 | issue = 7| pages = 1006–1007 |pmc=1738562 }}</ref> The mean [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] of current smokers was 6.0 points lower than the mean IQ of ex-smokers and 6.5 points lower than the mean IQ of those who had never smoked.<ref name="Deary et al., 2003" />
Physical fitness, indexed by a general [[Principal component analysis|component]] extracted from measures of lung function, grip strength and walk time, was associated with successful cognitive ageing at age 79 in the LBC1921.<ref name="Deary et al., 2006">{{cite journal |author1=Deary I. J. |author2=Whalley L. J. |author3=Batty G. D. |author4=Starr J. M. | year = 2006 | title = Physical fitness and lifetime cognitive change | doi = 10.1212/01.wnl.0000238520.06958.6a | journal = [[Neurology (journal)|Neurology]] | volume = 67 | issue = 7| pages = 1195–1200 }}</ref> Physical activity has also been associated with successful cognitive ageing in the LBC1936, as it remained associated with age 70 general cognitive ability and processing speed after controlling for intelligence at age 11.<ref name="Gow et al., 2012">{{cite journal |author1=Gow A. J. |author2=Corley J. |author3=Starr J. M. |author4=Deary I. J. | year = 2012 | title = Reverse causation in activity-cognitive ability associations: The Lothian Birth Cohort 1936 | doi = 10.1037/a0024144 | journal = [[Psychology and Aging]] | volume = 27 | issue = 1| pages = 250–255 }}</ref>
One of the strengths of the LBC study designs is that they enable tests of [[reverse causation]] in associations between intelligence and other variables. Reverse causation is implied if a contemporaneous association in old age is attenuated or eliminated after childhood intelligence is controlled for, which would suggest that the association existed partially or wholly due to the effects of earlier intelligence. Reverse causation has been separately reported for relationships in the LBC1936 between intelligence and each of caffeine consumption,<ref name="Corley et al., 2010">{{cite journal |author1=Corley J. |author2=Jia X. |author3=Kyle J. A. |author4=Gow A. J. |author5=Brett C. E. |author6=Starr J. M. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2010 | title = Caffeine consumption and cognitive function at age 70: The Lothian Birth Cohort 1936 study | doi = 10.1097/PSY.0b013e3181c92a9c | journal = [[Psychosomatic Medicine (journal)|Psychosomatic Medicine]] | volume = 72 | issue = 2| pages = 206–214 }}</ref> [[body mass index]],<ref name="Corley et al., 2010b">{{cite journal |author1=Corley J. |author2=Gow A. J. |author3=Starr J. M. |author4=Deary I. J. | year = 2010 | title = Is body mass index in old age related to cognitive abilities? The Lothian Birth Cohort 1936 study | doi = 10.1037/a0020301 | journal = [[Psychology and Aging]] | volume = 25 | issue = 4| pages = 867–875 }}</ref> alcohol consumption<ref name="Corley et al., 2011">{{cite journal |author1=Corley J. |author2=Jia X. |author3=Brett C. E. |author4=Gow A. J. |author5=Starr J. M. |author6=Kyle J. A. |author7=Deary I. J. | year = 2011 | title = Alcohol intake and cognitive abilities in old age: The Lothian Birth Cohort 1936 study | doi = 10.1037/a0021571 | journal = [[Neuropsychology (journal)|Neuropsychology]] | volume = 25 | issue = 2| pages = 166–175 }}</ref> and [[inflammation]].<ref name="Luciano et al., 2009b">{{cite journal |author1=Luciano M. |author2=Marioni R. E. |author3=Gow A. J. |author4=Starr J. M. |author5=Deary I. J. | year = 2009 | title = Reverse causation in the association between C-reactive protein and fibrinogen levels and cognitive abilities in an aging sample | doi = 10.1097/PSY.0b013e3181a24fb9 | journal = [[Psychosomatic Medicine (journal)|Psychosomatic Medicine]] | volume = 71 | issue = 4| pages = 404–409 }}</ref>

'''''Many Voices One World''''', also known as the '''MacBride report''', was a 1980 [[UNESCO]] publication written by the '''International Commission for the Study of Communication Problems''', chaired by [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] [[Nobel laureate]] [[Seán MacBride]]. Its aim was to analyze communication problems in modern societies, particularly relating to mass media and news, consider the emergence of new technologies, and to suggest a kind of communication order ([[New World Information and Communication Order]]) to diminish these problems to further peace and human development.
Among the problems the report identified were concentration of the media, commercialization of the media, and unequal access to information and communication. The commission called for democratization of communication and strengthening of national media to avoid dependence on external sources, among others. Subsequently, Internet-based technologies considered in the work of the Commission, served as a means for furthering MacBride's visions.
While the report had strong international support, it was condemned by the [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]] as an attack on the freedom of the press, and both countries withdrew from UNESCO in protest in 1984 and 1985, respectively (and later rejoined in 2003 and 1997, respectively).
==The MacBride Commission== The '''International Commission for the Study of Communication Problems''' was set up in 1977 by the director of UNESCO [[Ahmadou-Mahtar M’Bow]], under suggestion by the USA delegation. It was agreed that the commission would be chaired by Seán MacBride from Ireland and representatives from 15 other countries, invited due to their roles in national and international communication activities and picked among media activists, journalists, scholars, and media executives.
The members of the MacBride Commission were: * [[Elie Abel]] (USA) * [[Hubert Beuve-Méry]] (France) * [[Elebe Ma Ekonzo]] (Zaire) * [[Gabriel García Márquez]] (Colombia) * [[Sergei Losev (scientist)|Sergei Losev]] (Soviet Union) * [[Mochtar Lubis]] (Indonesia) * [[Mustapha Masmoudi]] (Tunisia) * [[Michio Nagai]] (Japan) * [[Fred Isaac Akporuaro Omu]] (Nigeria) * [[Bogdan Osolnik]] (Yugoslavia) * [[Gamal El Oteifi]] (Egypt) * [[Jan Pronk|Johannes Pieter Pronk]] (Netherlands) * [[Juan Somavía]] (Chile) * [[Boobli George Verghese]] (India) * [[Betty Zimmerman]] (Canada), in substitution of [[Marshal McLuhan]], then ill
The commission presented a preliminary report in October 1978 at the 20th General Conference of UNESCO in [[Paris]]. The Commission's seminal session on new technologies to address the identified problems, was hosted by India at [[New Delhi in March 1979]]. The final report was delivered to M’Bow in April 1980 and was approved by consensus in the 21st General Conference of UNESCO in [[Belgrade]]. The commission dissolved after presenting the report.
Because of controversy surrounding the report and the withdrawal of support by the UNESCO leadership in the 1980s for its ideas, the book went out of print and was difficult to obtain. A book on the history of the United States and UNESCO was even threatened with legal action and forced to include a disclaimer that UNESCO was in no way involved with it. The MacBride report was eventually reprinted by Rowman and Littlefield in the US, and is also freely available online.
==See also == *[[New World Information Order]] *[[International communication]]
==External links== *[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0004/000400/040066eb.pdf The Macbride report] ''Communication and Society Today and Tomorrow, Many Voices One World, Towards a new more just and more efficient world information and communication order''. Kogan Page, London/Uniput, New York/Unesco, Paris. Unesco, 1980. A French version is at [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0004/000400/040066fb.pdf] and a Spanish version at [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0004/000400/040066sb.pdf]
